transcripts.contents: Okay, good morning, my name's PERSON8 I'm from the ORGANIZATION7.

transcripts.contents: As well as using the data directly within the project, we release training data publicly where that's possible.

transcripts.contents: So, here is how the work package is organised.

transcripts.contents: It's led by ORGANIZATION7, ehm, ORGANIZATION2 and ORGANIZATION7 Health majority

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: And I'm going to talk briefly about each of these tasks.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: About what we've done so far, and also about some work that's currently in progress.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: So task one point one is about collecting, and preparing ASR training data and specifically it's about data for Czech.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: And so the background here is the ehm, start of the project.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: We already had ASR systems for six of the seven languages, but we didn't have a Czech system.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: When we go to the project proposal, we'd already identified some sources of transcribed audio data.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: With the Czech national radio being the main one.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: So the objective was to collect data and turn it into a form that's useful for training ASR.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: So for the uh, national radio data, the recordings ehm, come with high quality transcriptions and were taken from various radio programs.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: That ranges from eh, morning news programs to political debates.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: And the original recordings were suitable for training speech were those just because they are too long, typically twenty to fourty minutes long now is much too long for training acoustic models.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: So we developed a pipeline and that aligns the audio with the transcripts of the segment level and splits the recordings into much shorter pieces these are about ten to fifteen seconds long.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: This work has resulted in the creation of two hundred and sixty hours of speech training data.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: Using that, we were able to successfully train and deploy Czech ASR system.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: So ehm, a first version was used to the working group on VAT workshop in June last year.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: Subsequently, um, we built built systems using larger volumes of data, including the um, systems that are in in production in a subtitling pipeline.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: So subsequent to the work on the Czech national radio data we've collected over fourteen hundred hours of recordings from the ORGANIZATION15.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: We could just apply same processing pipeline.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: So we now have ehm ASR training data as well, and we took the sub-set of this data so about four hundred and fourty hours, which we have released publicly.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: And the data was described in in our paper that was published earlier this year.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: In addition, we've created our three Czech ASR test sets.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: Okay, and the second aspect of the task is about collecting data that can help to make a speech recognition system more robust, and especially the dialect and accent.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: Eh, so one source of non native speech data was the Fair of Student Firms, which was held in LOCATION1 eh, last year.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: And this was an event where high school students gave short presentations about fictitious companies and the pre- presentations had to be given in English.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: The students were non-native English speakers coming from nine different EU countries.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: So we recorded eh, presentations, and we asked the students to transcribe their own recordings.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: This was part of the competition.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: So they had an incentive to to do that.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: Um, we collected a total od thirty nine recordings averaging about ninety seconds in lengths and together with transcriptions.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: And from this we've created a test set, which can be used to test the robustness of recognition systems.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: Now this test set turned out to be extremely challenging, ehm, partly because of the the accents of speakers, and also because of some eh, noisy conditions of the event.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: So there was some background music and people coming in and

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: So even um, state-of-the art models that are adapted have have high error rates on the status.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: So it's a really challenging test set.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: We can try to improve against.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: Ehm, this work has been written up.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: It was published at the international conference on statistical language and speech processing last year.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: And it's also part of our test set for the IWSLT eh, twenty twenty shared task.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: So as a way of testing our own systems, and also staging the state-of-the art we organized shared task on non-native speech translation.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: And the data set was drawn from five different sources.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: Okay so in PROJECT2 we're trying to support ehm, of a huge number of language pairs.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: We have seven ehm, source languages, fourty three target languages.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: And ideally, we are trying, ehm, support every every one of those language pairs and we're also interested in very specific domain and the domain is auditing.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: Because there isn't ready made in- domain parallel corpus covering all those all of the language pairs we'd like.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: Eh, so we can't just go out and download a pre-existing data set.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: So task one point three is all about ehm, collecting data, for empty ESLT that covers as many of the languages as we possibly can.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: And that also includes some in-domain data.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: So one great, resource for machine translation, is OPUS, which is a huge collection of parallel corpora ehm, covering hundreds of language pairs.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: The data covers a wide range of domains and genres.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: There are translations of the Bible, subtitles from movies, Parliamentary proceedings, all kinds of things.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: So we sampled large multilingual parallel corpus, eh, suitable for training the the initial MT systems in the first version.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: We sampled up to one million sentence pairs for each language pair using up-sampling tool.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: The pairs were less data.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: The  corpus have two hundred twenty six million sentence pairs.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: A variant of this was OPUS one hundred, which covers a more diverse and slightly less Euro-centric ehm sort of languages.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: We use that for some research, which you will hear about later.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: And and that is now part of  collection itself.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: We have also been working on an extended data set.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: So this form  the artificial one million sentence pair limit.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: And and that's now in use for training ehm, IMT systems including some of those the or introduction in a  pipeline, and that some of you will see in other recent project images.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: So OPUS can give us a lot of data, but it's it's out of domain for our application.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: So for in-domain data we have to go out in crawl and prepare it ourselves.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: That was another EU project called Paracrawl, which is specifically focused on crawling parallel data from the Web.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: And we've been ehm, using version of their crawling pipeline for our work.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: So we started out by collecting data from one of the websites of the ORGANIZATION12  in ORGANIZATION5.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: And it has given us some monoligual data covering twenty four languages.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: Eh, some of those languages we're able to collect a lot of data.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: For others it was less, it  was more sparse.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: On on the average, we got a yield of fourty thousand sentences per language.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: We're now applying similar approach to extracting parallel corpora from the website of the ORGANIZATION4.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: And this is a really good resource, because the vast majority of the reports are published in all of the languages of the EU.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: So far we have extracted corpora for the pairs including English.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: And that has given us a pretty good yield that on average two hundred and eight thousand sentence pairs per language pair.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: And we're actively working on ehm, the language pairs that don't include English.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: So it was more data to come.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: We have also collected parallel data from a ORGANIZATION13.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: So ahead of the working group on VAT event we collected slides and other materials from the participants.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: And we used these to search through a similar sentences from the parallel corpora of ORGANIZATION13.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: This gave us an in-domain parallel data set, which we split into training and test portions.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: It covers eight language pairs as German to Czech, as well as certain pairs that have English in the source language.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: For the initial event we didn't have time to users to adapt our modules, but we have now used it for domain adaptation experiments.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: But we took models trained on OPUS corpus and fine tuned uh, using a training portion of the in-domain data.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: And in those experiments with saw uhm, some strong improvements in fine tuning when evaluating on these uh, in-domain test sets.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: So this one is a w- work in progress ehm, we're building a multi-parallel, multilingual corpus of speeches, transcripts, translations and simultaneous interpretations from ORGANIZATION10 planary sessions.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: The data cover the years, uh, two thousand and eight to two thousand eleven, when translations in to all twenty three EU languages were available, at least it was twenty three at the time.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: I think Croatian's been added since.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: Ehm, we received permission to use the interpreters voices for research purposes without we publish it, um, but the voices are accessible on the ORGANIZATION10 website.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: So it that's not a big obstacle to releasing the data.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: This is data set that can be used in various ways from treatment in ASR, for example, also in simultaneous SLT and multi-source SLT.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: Eh, so far we've downloaded speeches in eh, the twenty three languages with simultaneous interpretation into Czech, English and German.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: We're processing over twenty eight thousand speeches, not including the .

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: Um, so it's sixteen hundred speakers over a hundred hours, and a over eight million words of English transcripts or or translations.

transcripts.contents: Um, the distribution of the source languages is is somewhat unequal.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: So that's two hundred and thirty nine hours of English, hundred and ten of German, and then less for other other languages.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: Okay, task one point four is about collecting data for minuting, ehm automatic minuting.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: Its the most challenging task to collect data for um, since there're very few pre-existing resources.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: Um, as a rule we have been collecting and annotating  from scratch.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: So this involves making audio recordings of meetings and and producing transcripts just like in ASR, but also collecting em, pre-prepared agendas and meeting minutes, which may have been created by the organizers, , secretaries of the meeting.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: And then this data eh, has to be manually annotated by two different annotators with the main idea of the annotation ehm, being that we connect segments of the audio recordings or the ASR transcripts with the corresponding items in the minutes.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: We've been collecting data from our own meetings as well as meetings for other EU projects and meetings of of other groups at ORGANIZATION2.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: So far, we've collected approximately a hundred hours of meetings in English, and over fifty hours of meetings in Czech.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: In the English language meetings, most of the participants are non-native speakers.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: So this is actually a really challenging data set for ASR as well.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: This corpus is still under active development.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: So far, it's been used as a test set for some preliminary experiments on meeting summarization.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: And we continue into collecting  data.

transcripts.contents: Also, we have an open call for data.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: And we're hoping to collect recordings and minutes from ehm, more sources with view to running shared task.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12
transcripts.contents: Okay, so those are the four tasks make up the ehm, data work package, ehm  the data need to project diverse and collect it training test data from wide range of sources.

transcripts.contents: Ehm, recen- recent initiative starting earlier this year is PROJECT2 test set.

transcripts.contents: This is a  repository where we collect together, uh, the data eh, that we use to evaluate our ASR MT and SLT systems.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON12

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: So um, I will try to give you an an insight into the research that has been going on at the work package two on automatic speech recognition.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: Um, so the goal of work package two is to develop the uh, speech recognition systems that are needed in the the um, ah, speech, translation pipeline of the PROJECT2 spoken language translation system.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: In an order for the ASR systems to be usable within that system they have to meet a couple of different criteria.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: So they have to eh, transcribe the speech to text, but they also need to be running in real time.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: They need to run with low word based latency.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: That is the time span from a time that the word has spoken till until it is put out.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And ehm, of course the test run in acceptable performance and for a diverse set of languages.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: So currently the languages of interest that we have identified for PROJECT2 are Czech, German, English, French, Italian, Spanish and Russian.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And as rough target performances we've set that we want to reach word error rate below fifteen percent.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: Even better if we could go below ten percent.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: Um, so at the outset of the project, the state- of- the-art -

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: So we have an ehm, at the outset of the project the state-of-the art was to do our online low latency speech recognition with hybrid HMM/ANN systems that implemented base classifier and consist of an acoustic model that models the class based probability of an audio sequence given foot sequence MP ah,  probability of a work sequence as a language eh, model.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And these systems could run in streaming mode with real time at low latency, and with an acceptable peroformance.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: So the artificial neural networks of these systems were used for estimating the um emission probabilities in a hidden Markov model.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And that again was then used to do the acoustic model.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: While the language model was always realized with ANN language models.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: Um, at the same time at the onset of the project there was also quite active research in sequence to sequence models that do not do use an base approach.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: But directly use neural networks to output the optimal most likely word sequence.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And there were different competing systems there.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: So one was based on a neural ehm, ehm, target training function called connectionist temporal classification or CTC short for optimizing neural networks that do exactly that that output either directly carries word sequences, for example, using long, short term memory networks.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And there were also, other, uhm, approaches that used an encoder, decoder with attention model that encode an audio signal represented by a feature sequence X into annotation vector and then decode that one into the target se- symbol sequence for except the characters or word.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: That um, even though these models gave better performance than the hybrid models, they were not able to run at low latency and eh, in real in an online streaming mode.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: So at the beginning of the project eh, they were not ah, suitable for our purposes here in PROJECT2.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: Ah, the work package two has a structure of three tasks.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: Ehm, the first task aims at improving the robustness, especially in terms of hybrid ASR systems of the acoustic model so that they are more robust to different factors, such as different speakers, dialects, accents, acoustic conditions, but also domains in terms of topics.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And ehm for hybrid, the old hybrid systems there were many hm, techniques to deal with these, but with the new neural methods ehm, there was a need now to to invent methods to develop new methods to become more robust against all these factors.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And to do that for the sequence to sequence model this is especially challenging to find new adaptation ehm methods.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: Ehm, the second task, um, was concerned with adapting the language model, because in the old traditional systems the language model is more or less responsible for being specific to assist a specific domain.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: So the acoustic model have specifity to the acoustic conditions.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: While the language model has the specifity to towards the topics that the speech recognition system um, is supposed to work on.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And eh, ASR systems the old ones were always best when adapted and tailored to the target domain as closely as possible.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And that is often difficult, because for many domains, it's difficult to get a matching training data.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: For example, for the ORGANIZATION9 domain it can be difficult to obtain the matching training data.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: So what what here needs to do is we have to learn a Semi-Supervised ur Unsupervised fashion starting from small amounts of subdata and trying to exploit that as much as possible.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: In order to be able to adapt a, eh, background language model that has been trained on a more generic corpus.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And then the third task is to deal with the fact that in eh, the traditional way that we train ASR systems usually you have a training phase and the tuning phase.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And once the model is eh, trained and validated it is then sent out into the real world in order to perform in the real system.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: But the models of the system remain static.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: That's the old way.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: But the real world doesn't work that way because ehm, um, the domains, ah, are constantly changing in terms of linguistics.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: For example, new words and topics are invented, other topics and words are being dropped.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: But you also see new eh, speakers, new accents, new dialects et cetera.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: So the environment in which such system operates constantly changes.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And therefore the systems should not stay static, but should continue to lo- to learn while they are being deployed.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And that's what we want to do in the third task.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: So with respect to the work package progress.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: Ah, um, as shown in the deliverable two point one, we have provided the first set of ASR systems that can be used in the uh, different showcases of PROJECT2.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And we have provided um speech recognition systems for and there's Czech, English, French, German, Italian and Spanish.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And we're while doing that we examined different architecture.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: So the hybrid, HMM/ANN models, then a sequence-to-sequence model, which is more based on encoder decoder plus attention.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And then a completely new model which is based on the self attention, which in a machine translation way often is called a transformer based model.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And then for robustness we ehm, looked at different kinds of robustness.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: So we experimented with neural codes for language robustness.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: Eh, we did eh, developed this new transformer base speech recognition system.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: Um, we looked at robustness towards domains and eh, different topics with the encoder eh, decoder based ehm models.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And then we also um, looked in two ways of making these decoder encoder based models perform in a streaming mode with a low word based latency.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: When it comes to the second task, where we looked at the adaptation of the language models eh, the consortium performed experiments on in Czech for hybrid HMM/ANN systems.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And then finally, in order to prepare work for the lifelong learning task.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: We created the first interface that allows us to collect manual corrections supervisions from users of a speech translation system.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And then in the second half of the project we will perform the research on the data that we collect with this eh, interface in order to be able to learn a lifelong fashion.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: Um, this is an overview over the different languages that we covered with the ASR development.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: We've we have HMM/ANN systems and we have encoder decoder based systems eh, with attention.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And so for all languages Czech, English, German, French, Spanish and Italian hybrid system is available.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And for English also a first eh, decoder encoder plus attention based system is now available that meets all the development criteria, and actually outperforms the hybrid eh, system.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: Um the interesting thing of the encoder decoder based attention system is that it runs now in streaming mode.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: So you remember from the the intermediate review that we wanted to make a decision on whether we are able to do this actually to do a streaming recognition with this sequence to sequence models.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And we actually within the first period managed to to achieve that goal, so that we can run now with the latency of two seconds.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And the really interesting thing is that we don't see really a degradation in word error rate, if you compare that to the offline system.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: So the streaming recognition in English is now basically just as good as the offline recognition.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And these are not just any numbers.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: But these are really state-of-the art performance on standard benchmarks.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And an English worker is now available and can be deployed.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: So the the the only thing that we now need to organize is that we have the the uh, available computational resources to run that in large scale.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: Because the neural models need graphical processing units TPUs in order to run.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: Um with respect to the multilingual re- robustness we had experimented with something that we called language uh, codes neural language codes.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And the idea behind that is that you train the language identification system with the bottleneck and the activation at the bottleneck is a code that represents the properties of the language that you put into the language identification system.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And now if you put in, er,  a language that you haven't seen during training of the LID system, you still get a neural code out of the LID system that captures in the continuous vector space the properties of that languages.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And you can use these language codes in order to eh, condition neural networks in order to better adept themselves in an unsupervised/semi-supervised manner to the language that has being put into the recognition system.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And we did some experiments with this in a CTC set up where we use the neural language codes to modulate LSTM networks that were trained in CTC.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And the interesting thing is that if you know, multilingual system in the good old days, if you would make several languages together to train a hybrid system, performance would be great.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: But if you now use modulation with LID on the multilingual system, uhm, you can actually bring it at par with a monolingual system.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: So just performs as well as a monoligual system.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And if we put uh, some more effort into it and have a ah, ah, super network, based on the uh, Meta Pi network.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: We can actually get word error rates that are below of the monolingual system.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: So they um the ASR systems are now actually able to learn from ah, many different languages, and give better performance in one of the languages.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: When it comes to multi-domain robustness, so robustness to different topics, we ehm, know from the par- past that if you have a hybrid system and you train it on a whole  of different training data for different domains, and then you test one specific domain, performance might actually degrade.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: If you like have training data that mismatches your target domain.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And our working hypothesis was that what we've een from previous research that neural network based ASR systems are more robust to mixing different styles of training data.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And all hy- hypothesis was that with an encoder decoder based ASR system we even can improve over matched training data if we pool also missmatched training data into the system training.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: So in order to test that hypothesis, we constructed the multi-domain corpus with a total of one thousand six hundred hours of data.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And this multi-domain corpus was pooled from publicly available data in English.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And it contained read speech, planned speech, spontaneous speech.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: With respect to topics we had news broadcasts, we had tech talks, we had lectures, we had phone calls.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And when it comes to signal eh, variations, we had telephone speech, and word bent speech in the training data.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: Eh, so these are the different corpora we had in there and with the different hours, number of hours.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: So you can see that different corpora have different number of hours in their training data.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And they cover the whole range of these eh, different, three different dimensions that I mentioned before.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: Ah, so what our experiment showed, that actually the encoder decoder based model slot very fell from this multi-domain sets.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And while hybrid AMM/HMM/ANN models are always best if you train in a single domain condition with a domain adapted language model.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: Ah, with the encoder plus attention based models we can train on this multi-domain car-corpus and get similar hm, word error rates as the specific hybrid, uhm models.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And in order to do that, we use to technique diff- diff eh, similar to the multilingual experiment that we did before.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: So instead of having a neural language code we now have sort of a neural domain ID code that we also learn from a bottleneck the eh, eh layer from a neural network that tries to identify the domains.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And we can now condition our networks by pending this domain with  input.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And if we do that, um, when it comes to in-domain, domain specific testing we get the same word error rate with the hybrid models.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And the really nice thing is that if we now test on the domain that we have not seen eh, before, so out-of domain corpus that we haven't seen during training.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: These domain conditioned models actually outperform eh, the hybrid eh, models.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: Um, so here's some word error rate numbers that show that we've switched for TED-talks, um, read books, audio books, broadcast news.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And then Skype calls, the Microsoft spoken language test set as a test sets.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: The MLST test set is the out-of domain test set.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: So if we have the domain specific HMM/ANN models, we basically get the same performance if we have domain-specific HMM/ANN with the multi-domain trained encoder decoder.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And then if we go to the out-of domain corpus, we see that with the domain conditioning, the encoder decoder is significantly better on the out-of domain corpus than the hybrid ANN- HMM/ANN systems.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: Ah, when it comes to the robustness of the acoustic model, there were also experiments performed with a differed ASR architecture.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: That is a combination of phoneme level acoustic models, so a network that outputs eh, phonemes.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: In the experiment there was Jasper used, which is essentially a convolutional neural network eh, trained to output phonemes using the CTC crit PERSON12.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And then on top of this acoustic model, a transformer-based translation system performed translation from phonemes to gra- graphemes.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: Ehm, so when this is applied to clean training data, the performance is not really eh, much worse than that of ey, baseline system.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And this um, performance can be improved when using um, colla- collapted training data.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: That is most similar to what a acoustic model would put out.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And if it is combined with transformer -

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: I will have some more details on the slides eh, on these experiments.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: Then we also looked at robustness to data augmentation because for sequence to sequence end-to-end ASR overfitting is still one of the most prominent models.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And usually data augmentation is used to counteract that problem.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: Um, most common technique is the specAugment which does spectral and temporal masking and we added some additional techniques.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: For one we added dynamic time stretching, ah, um, with online perturbation in the spectral domain.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: So instead of speed perturbation in the time domain, we hear by avoiding the shifted pitch.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And we also use sub-sequences sampling in order to have more linguistic data augmentation of the output sequences.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And when we apply that, we can see that our sequence to sequence models essentially the achieve a word error rate that is uhm, more or less comparable with the best performing systems on switchboard and CallHome.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And the best performing switchboard is actually a s- combination of five different systems, while we basically reach the same region of word error rate by using one single  system.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: Ehm then, when it comes to the adaptation of the language models that was work performed on Czech.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: Where a Czech hybrid ASR system that was based on Kaldi was adapted to different domains and the adaptation was done on the language model.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: So the different domains that were used to the experiments were ORGANIZATION15 speeches from the ORGANIZATION15, c- speeches in Czech from the ORGANIZATION10 and presentations on computational linguistics, conferences of the ORGANIZATION12 in LOCATION1 and Czech broadcast news.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And in order to do the adaptation different types of adaptation data was collected like slides, papers, newspaper articles and key words that are later to the target domain.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And the slides we will also finish futhermore with some results.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And then finally, for the lifelong learning we had the preparatory work where we are eh, implemented this editor that allows um to -

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: If the video - would load - I guess I will replace the video with a just a couple of eh of pictures.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: So where we were able to eh, now have multi-user collaborative edits on transcriptions on translations of recordings of ehm, talks.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And all different kinds of of spoken language translation se- sessions.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And then we can exploit these edits in order to do a lifelong learning.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: So what is the outlook for the rest of the project.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: So we now ehm, aim at ehm coming up with encoding decoding encoder decoder plus attention ASR systems for all languages of PROJECT2 to to be used at the PROJECT2 framework.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: We will perform experiments in lifelong learning based on the user edits eh, with ORGANIZATION14 that we got from the ORGANIZATION14 editing platform.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And we will do more experiments techniques on robustness towards languages, acce- accents, general conditions et cetera for the end-to-end speech recognition systems.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And some of the things that I can also p- already promise for the next review, but they don't fall into the reporting period of this this review any more is some first recipes for lifelong learning based on eh, fine-tuning looking at different aspects of how how to do the fine-tuning.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: For different things like accents, domains, et cetera and I w- will also report on being able to reach human performance in English ASR in real time and low latency on a switchboard task.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON24
transcripts.contents: And with that I am open for your questions.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON13
transcripts.contents: Ehm thank you.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON13
transcripts.contents: Thank you for the presentation.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Oh Hi, ehm, okay, so I'm PERSON1 and I'm presenting the  work package three spoken language translation.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Okay, so spoken language translation is essentially it's the bit that joins the ASR and MT together.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So eh, it's about how we get um, say the noisy output from MT from ASR which is is a spoken style into something resembling subtitles.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So essentially, we have two different models for doing this.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Uh, the first is is the one, we're mainly using in production, which is the pipeline model.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Where ca- we connect together essentially three different systems.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Eh we have an ASR system to make the transcripts.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And then we have a componental module which basically ties up the transcript, makes it more suitable for machine translation.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And then we have the machine translation component.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: We've also been invent- em experimenting with the end-to-end systems where the goal of that is essentially to have one system that takes in the audio and produces the ouput text.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So with that sort of split in mind -

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Eh, yeah.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So the way we put together the work package.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: We thought of that as three different tasks.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So the first task is sort of  ASR ouput  you assume a pipeline system.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: We take the ASR output and we try to make it more suitable for machine translation.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: The second task is sort of coming in the other direction, where we take the the machine translation system and try to make it more try to try to make it better cope with ASR output.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And third task is way you can edit  together, and just try to do things from it in an end- to- end fashion.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So that is just the structure.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: This talk is based on the zoom through the different bits of research that we've done in this work package.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Ehm, em and in terms of their connection with the tasks, what we what we have actually done.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: This is the way we wrote proposal that there is there is quite a lot of tasks that are connected with this idea of how we take online ASR and first to build an MT system that cope with that.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And secondly, try to build on it online SLT system.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So we put it that in into three point two, because it is basically about how we convert the MT system to make it deal with the ASR.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So with that said ehm -

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: The first first thing to mention is segmentation

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So segmentation is the bit - it it's not just segmentation.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: It's the bit that goes between the ASR and the MT in a life system.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And the typical jobs it has to do are things like the normalization, removal of disfluencies, addition of punctuation, dealing with cases and splitting into sentences.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So we have essentially two segmenters.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um, they are both roughly speaking sequence-to-sequence models.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um, the reason we have two is that, um, we started off with the ORGANIZATION14 segmenter.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: We found that it was kind of tied to to the ORGANIZATION14's ASR.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So at at ORGANIZATION2 we started with an another segmentation effort.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um, because we're also building ehm, building ASR at ORGANIZATION2.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um, so these are these are fairly simple models, which eh, use sequence-to-sequence models and some rules to produce more like  output.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Ehm, oh, yeah.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: I mentioned at the start that the ASR's online.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So this is an example of the the output of ASR.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um we basically just co-  again these updates and the updates to to do one of two things.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Either the it's -

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Well, yeah, the the updates either extend ehm the hypothesis, or they rewrite part of the hypothesis.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And you see, you know, if you look at the last update you can get changes to the segmentation.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So the ASR is delivered incrementally what we do with the SLT.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So when we think about how to develop the SLT, the first one of the first things we thought about is, how do we actually evaluate it.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Ehm, the tradit-traditionally, you know, you evaluate you evaluate MT using BLEU score on sentences.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: This doesn't quite work for the SLT because you have got other things to think about.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And really they fall into three different that the three different things we wish to evaluate.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: The first thing is the latency.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So - eh, the latency becomes a bit tricky.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: When you try, let let us think about a system level that we just think of the MT level, you are looking at the delay between receiving that from ASR and producing the translation.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Ehm, so there are questions about how to how to actually evaluate that.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: I mean how do I actually link the ASR ouput with the translation of that output.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And then the second thing, which is maybe not obvious is the idea of a flicker.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So if you're if your ASR is rewriting and extending and you're constantly translating, then you your MT will start rewriting and and reordering and so on.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So if you just open up  you get this flicker with things move around on the screen.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um, so you can measure that using something like edit-distance.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And the last thing is also the quality.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Ehm, so it's it's evaluated with, you know, we all know how to evaluate the MT quality.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um, we use one of the automatic metrix.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Ehm the difficulty with ASR output with all the  spoken language is a thing about the segmentation.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Uhm, and then you have this thing - you have got this extending going on.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: How do we - how do we evaluate that, and what we do is we just evaluate full sentences.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So thinking about the evaluation we looked around.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And there is not really any good tools to to do this evaluation.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So this is something we have been working on.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: We have this thing called LST sorry SLTF which is an open source evaluation tool.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: The idea is for it to be like the sacreBLUE of ehm SLT.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So uh, we we have a few different versions of different metrix that have been suggested.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um, it delegates a sacreBLEU for for evaluation of MT.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: But we have um within SLTF we have evaluations of of the latency and flicker along with the different variants.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um, so this was used in IWSLT shared task eh, this year.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um, also in the IWSLT shared task we participated as PROJECT2.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um, and this give us the opportunity to to try the different tools that we can creating for doing ASR and MT and connect them together.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So we took I think seven different ASR systems, including online ones, and offline ones.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And various different combinations of MT systems, and try them all together to choose the best one in a sort of competitive framework.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And then submitted is as the PROJECT2 system for this non-native SLT task and not only was it not native speech, but it had an online aspects.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um and so we had to submit the the time stamps for for our eh, translation.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And these were judged by the SLTF tool.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So the conclusions from that task were that non-native speech recognition that's a really hard.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um, so the ASR forms did not form very well, for for many reasons, um.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So the end the pipeline you know, you are getting BLEU score about five.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So it is not really very good.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um, it also fell back into the -

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Through the task we learn to a bit about the evaluation tool and how it worked to evaluate feedback into it's development.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um, so moving on to -

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: We've been talking about online SLT ehm, so the way we think about this is there's kind of roughly two different methods for doing online SLT.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um,  when you've got an online ASR.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: The first method, which is the one we use in  is called the retranslation method.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And in this method we we saw the MT is more the more the receiver.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um, so ASR pushes messages to MT.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: There's two different types of messages .

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Either the ASR extensive stable region.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So it says, oh you know, this transcription I gave you.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: I'm not gonna change that that is unstable.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Or it rewrites the unstable region.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So the unstable region is the bit that may change.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And it can either ex- get extended, or it can get altered.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And retranslation approach is really simple.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: It's just like every time, the ASR updates the unstable region the MT translates.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: It doesn't retranslate everything.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Full sentences are considered complete once are stable so they're they aren't retranslated.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: But I mean, typically, you can have two to three sentences in the unstable region, and they're constantly get retranslated.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: The other option is is the streaming option.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And this one is sort of CMT as being in control and the MT has two actions.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Either it can it can wait for more input from the ASR or it can translate and send to user.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um, uh, this works a bit differently, because it requires some kind of modified inference and some kind of learning.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So the MT can learn when to ehm when to retranslate.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Sorry when to when to translate and when to wait.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Ehm, so we use retranslation approach 'cause that is really simple.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: We can use that with that standard MT tool ORGANIZATION14, um with a very simple wrapper, um.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And at the moment, we don't um, we consider flicker to be quite bad.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Ehm especially if the if the translation isn't very good.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Then it has flicker a lot.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So the actual current production rate of the ASR stabilized .

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Ehm, so a couple of things that we can do to improve the retranslation approach.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: The first thing is that ehm if the if the MT system doesn't see prefixes as an ehm, incomplete sentences in training.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: It doesn't do very well.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So training that prefixes does help.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And the nice thing is you do not have to mess about the aligners to produce the prefix d- you ju- just truncate.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: I'm  these in training.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Makes it slightly worsen full sentences but it makes it better on prefixes.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: The other thing we do, which is a simple idea, ehm, from a paper by Arivazhagan is is masking.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Where basically you don't, you just mask the last key words of the outputs.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: You translate, but you don't send the whole translation you mask the last keywords.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So that's kind of a blind test meant very simple.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Eh, but one thing we thought about is can we improve on that?

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Ehm, so we improve by doing something called dynamic masking.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So if you use a fix mask, you end up with quite a lot of latency.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: I mean in the fix mask it's is shown in a red dotted line in this graph.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So the graph is showing the latency against the um, the flicker.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um, and the way we did dynamic mask, is we try to look look at the translation and predict how how stable it is.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And we do this by basically extending.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So we get the source of the from the ASR and we try different extensions of the source.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: We just basically predict what the next source word might be.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And then try translating them.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And if we see lot of instability in those translations, then we use a long mask.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And if we don't see much instability.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: We try try various extensions and use the same thing that we do not alter the mask very much.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And that gives us a better ehm latency flicker tradeoff.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So that was work we published at AMSA.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um, the next thing is again addressing the latency.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Basically latency quality trade-off is -

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And this is going to the streaming approach.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um, where we we we ex- exploit a a thing called adaptive computation time, which was reduced introduced a few years ago.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um and the idea is that worsening code of encoder decoder networks.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And the essential idea is the decoder.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So you have the encoder, which takes the input and encodes it, but the decoder has basically two options.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: It can either ponder, so it can wait for more encoder steps.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Or it can it can produce output.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: We showed this working for essentially machine translation on unsegmented ASR output.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: But our plan is to make this work work for end-to end SLT on completely unsegmented audio.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So that don't we can do the segmentation as well in the whole pipeline.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Ehm, okay.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So this is moving on to thinking about, um, how do we do with the noise in ASR.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um so, the noise -

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Sorry.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: The re- MT can suffer, because is essentially trai- a mismatch between training and inference.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So the training data is using very clean  transcripts or basically clean text.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Ehm a test time, or or inference time, we are using noisy output of speech recognition.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So how do you deal with that?

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Well, oa- one way we've looked at is ehm, to try to model the noise.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So the method is basically to run some data through ASR and look at the errors.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And then we build a model for creating artificial noise.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Ehm, and artifical noise basically consists of things like ehm adding  function words, changing function words, changing verb tenses, pluralizing, depluralizing.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And then a bunch of ehm, let's say acoustic confusion trying to find words and sounds like sound like so inject them to the MT training data and retrain.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So that gives us a consistent improvement.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: We did some experiments with English to Chinese.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Ehm, it gives some consistent improvement on the when you're translating ASR output, but not when you're translating gold transcripts, which is what we expect to happen.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um, when looking in more details, it's bit a harder to link that to the to the noise models.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So r- sort of suspecting that there is also regularization going on when injecting this noise, which may be causing the game.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: We are not really sure.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um, related to that is another ehm, piece of work we did where instead of instead of translating directly from the audio.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Sorry it - it's like pipeline approach.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: In the pipeline approach we go from the audio basically to the written text.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: The graphemes, if you like, to add them to the translation.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: But what if you go from the audio to the phonemes.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So you don't actually go to fill speech represent- eh full writen representation.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And then you add them to do the translation.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: That could help with the robustness.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: I think it could because you sort - you sort of preserving the different interpretations of those phonemes rather than committing to some written form.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Ehm, and it could definitelly help if you have a that a language s-ah- transliteration that may well have help with the entities.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: We haven't tested that yet.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Ehm, we have some results for English to Czech.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And what it showing is that in this second part of the table with the ASR source source when we use phonemes as the intermediate representation we get some improvements.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Only at the long, the lower the the larger beam sizes.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: But we get no real difference when we have got a clean beam and that which is kind of what we expect.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Ehm, so that brings us forward into end-to-end translation.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um, where yeah, the idea is, the goal is basically have to take the input and then the output audio and produce a direct eh, trans- translation.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So what the advantages of that.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: I think that the main sort of ideas that is gonna be a much simpler model.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: You know, we don't have to have to have this complicated deployment pipeline.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: We can have one model, which does the ASR segmentation the MT.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Eh, connected with that is is is the notion that it should improve the coupling.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: The ASR and the MT should work together, because they train together.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And it it gives us should give some more efficient inference and make it and should make it simpler to do this online SLT which we are trying to do.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um, one of the big problems that has end to end SLT faced is the is the lack of end to end data.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So basically, you need, say, you need like English audio paired with ehm Czech eh, translations ehm, and there's limited amount of this.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Ehm, whereas if you want English audio put- if you want to build pipelines system, you have very large amount of English training data.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And for a translation sets we have a lot of English to Czech translation.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So the the techniques that we're using is things like um transfer learning system, kind of pre-training some kind of multitask training.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And we have been developing certain architecture improvements, which help with the get over the  issue.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Ehm, so on the end to end translation system.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: One of the claims for end to end translation is this this kind of robustness.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So it should be more resistant to noise.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So we set out to examine this.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So I'm going to explain this this this this graph.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Ehm, we experimented with English to Spanish on end to end translation.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Ehm, and what we did was, we added increasing decreasing noise to the inference data.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And that is what the X- axis represents.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: It goes from raw as a no noise to very noisy input.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And it shows blue on the Y-axis.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And the pairs of lines are showing an end to end system and a pipeline system.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So that, for example, the blue solid line and the blue dotted line, both show paired end to end systems and pipeline systems.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And the different colours represents the different training conditions, we actually injected the noise during training to try different conditions.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: What we see from this is, there isn't really any evidence that the end to end system is more robust.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Essentially the blue th- the dotted lines and the solid lines are essentially parallel as far as you can see.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So there isn't strong evidence from here that we are getting more robustness.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um, this is this is essentially one one language per one one noise injection.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um, but yeah, we don't see any evidence at the moment.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Further work that we've done on end to end translation has come from this idea that speech signals very data sparse.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So you, you know, the important parts of containing quite small sections.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um, so how do we exploit this.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: The idea is to learn feature selector before we learn the translation.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: have this work.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Ehm, so the method is as appear in the in the enumeration.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: We first we train the ASR encoder um.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: That were trained as our system, which includes ASR encoder.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And then we have another phase where we learn this feature selector.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um, and feature selector that we use is this is the  cell zero drop, which is up, um, which encourages sparcity, using this L zero-based objective.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um, and then we trained the SLT with these just with these selected features, instead of using a full output from ASR encoder.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And that get rid gets rid an awful lot of the ehm, ASR input and gives us some improvement on Bleu analysis and speed up.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Like one, let's say one four percent speed up in an inference time.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: I'm showing here results of linguistic German.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: But we actually have pretty similar results across the whole of the massy data sets.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um, so that's where we are.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Ehm, okay.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: So, may- I'm talking on problems here.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Ehm,

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: We have this we still have this flicker latency trade-off pro- problem.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: What we've done that these to date to make it useful make it good for users is to remove flicker altogether.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: That gives a large latency.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Ehm, I I think possibly if that systems were stronger then flicker wouldn't be such a problem.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um, we also find that if if the ASR degrades in the MT MT quality dropped quite rapidly.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: You know, for example, get per per- per acoustics and the MTs becomes very poor.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: But also, we have the wrong segmentation.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Um, that makes it very difficult for the MT to cope was very difficult thing for the MT to cope with.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Also the - and this connects a bit with work package five.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: And and also with the  the ideal flicker.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: You you got this notion of cognitive load, if the transcripts are not and the translations are not that good or they're too long and they're flickering, all these things make it very difficult for the user to read.So we're still kind of optimistic that e- end to end SLT was can adress some of these problems.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: You know, for example, dealing with un-segmented audio.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1
transcripts.contents: Uhm, coming about online SLT it does not work much better than that so far.

transcripts.speaker: PERSON1

transcripts.contents: Um, okay.Thank you.
